comments.author: Peter Dunne
comments.comment:
The underlying methods here have been deprecated. We should not being introducing any further references to FIPExternalSupport.
Instead use ProxyRetriever.getProxy(..).
See http://jira/browse/FAB-1495 and http://jira/browse/FPL-5080 for further details.

comments.author: Daniel Delgado
comments.comment: In deed, the updated code is wrong. For creating a new ExtensionCase, first time is mandatory to use ProxyCreator.createProxy(...).

comments.author: Peter Dunne
comments.comment: Never used?

comments.author: Peter Dunne
comments.comment: Not used.

comments.author: Peter Dunne
comments.comment: As above, shouldnt be introducing more references to *.getProxyForGui

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment:
Since the screen is divided in 4 areas (Evaluations, Medical Review, Resources and Provide Training) can we replace this by: isEvaluations() || isMedicalReview() || isResources() || isProvideTraining()
and then create each 4 with the booleans for each area? This way makes the code more readable.

comments.author: Hugo Dias

Since it can be one of 4 values from the enum, why not test by the negative?
return !isNotApplicable();

comments.author: Colin Doyle
Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Updated javadoc

comments.author: Colin Doyle
comments.comment: Is there an existing test around this method? If not, I would recommend one.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Tihs is existing private method. I don't really want to refactor it out of the widget. Would you suggest I use Deencapsulation.java to test it or otherwise?

comments.author: Colin Doyle
comments.comment: Must it be private? Is default package protection not sufficient for this? I would not recommend using Deencapsulation as you cannot see from the call hierarchy where the test is being tested.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Test added

comments.author: Colin Doyle
comments.comment: Are there any unit tests for this class? I would recommend one for makeApplicationCategory().

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Not currenrtly. As above, private method........what are your approach(es) to testing these?

comments.author: Colin Doyle
comments.comment: Keep the methods default package protected unless absolutely necessary to have them private, e.g. a highly secure method. makeApplicationCategory() does not appear to be such.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Made package access, added tests.

comments.author: Colin Doyle
comments.comment:
Minor also - feel free to discard, as is a matter of style.
I would not assign internally to a method and return a string in the same method. It is not obvious that it assigns to the “context” attribute when the method signature returns a String. Ordinarily, I would invoke that method, then assign the result to the “context” attribute, i.e. outside the method. Both work, but for not wanting to look at the implementation of each method, I would have done so outside of it. Otherwise, a void return type is an option.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: I cant really change the signature as its overridden from the super class. I wanted to store the context as part of its creation, for later use. I cant think of a clean way to separate those two based on that restriction?

comments.author: Colin Doyle
Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Too risky change in such an important page, dropping issue

comments.author: Colin Doyle
comments.comment: Lots of good tests here! I’m assuming the line was drawn not to test getCaseCustomiserInstance as it was deemed unnecessary as it’s a well-trodden path.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Again not public, any ideas?

comments.author: Colin Doyle
comments.comment: The risk of making such as method default package protected looks very low in this instance. When comparied with the benefit of having making the code testable, I always veer and advise to veer towards default package protection unless extremely sensitive.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Tests added

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: These should be on separate lines

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Same comment for APP.scripts in all folders

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: No commits in upgrade scripts. The SQL upgrade runner adds these after each script. Otherwise, it cannot re-run a script if it fails.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Same comment for scripts

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: As above, no commit

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Put your enum script last

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
No javadoc, are these subsets or what?
INTAKE_SOURCE_ALL_EXCEPT_UNKNOWN........not sure if this is a good idea. What is someone adds a new instance.....they may not add it to this subset, then that new instance will not appear, and the subset will no longer make sense. IMO you should get the instances and remove the unknowing instance, using EnumUtils.getFilteredEnumInstances(). This is a safer approach

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Do we really need this complexity? Cant we just show the full enum, with Unknown, and allow the project team to make Unknown inactive if they want, meaning it wont show up? This is how I would handle this. Can you chat with Maura about this approach?
